newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Indonesians buy meal, said looking for more - trade.
newsitem.headline: Indonesians buy meal, said looking for more - trade.

text.p: Indonesia recently bought a Handy-sized cargo of optional origin soymeal from South America and is said to be looking for at least 50,000 tonnes more of meal, dealers said on Thursday.
"I believe they bought one cargo of meal for June shipment," a dealer for a commodity house in Singapore said.
"The deal makes sense," a trader for U.S. commodity firm said. "Easily, the Indonesians should be looking to pick up 50,000 tonnes more of meal. They need to fill up those positions."
The price paid by the Indonesian buyer was not immediately available, dealers said.
But South American meal was being quoted by the trade at a US$30-$50 discount to U.S. meal, which was quoted in Southeast Asia between $383-$385 a tonne C&F for June/July shipment.

"Nobody is looking at U.S. meal. We're going to ship South American meal," a dealer said. High protein meal from the U.S. was being quoted by regional dealers as high as $400 a tonne C&F for June/July shipment.
"The Indonesians are looking for meal at around $315 to $320 (a tonne). They should be going for at least two more cargoes," a dealer with a European trading house said.
Other buyers around the region were said to be looking to fill up open positions for soymeal and soybeans, but are discouraged by the current high futures prices in Chicago.
"Everybody is looking for cargo, but they're waiting for prices to come off. It's just waiting, waiting and waiting," a trader added.
The spot May contract on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) hit a contract high on Wednesday of $303 a ton against the previous high of $300 a ton on Tuesday.
In the grains market, the region was quiet with the trade waiting for word on whether buyers in the Philippines would complete negotiations to buy 75,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat.

"One group is looking for 35,000 tonnes while another group is close to clinching a deal for 40,000 tonnes. They see wheat prices going up so they want to lock in their prices now," one trader in Manila said.
The corn market was quiet with the Malaysians having put on extensive coverage while the Thais sat it out.
Moslem holidays in Malaysia and Indonesia will probably keep the trade quiet over the next day or two.
"It should be quiet for now," a dealer said.
"The Malaysians are pretty comfortable at the moment with the stocks they have. Nobody wants to do anything today and I don't think that will change," another trader said.
